what: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs
title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs
text: poisonfrogs extensive collection 31 colour palettes inspired Neotropical poison frogs. 200 brighly colored species, Neotropical poison frogs paint rain forest vivid hues shout clear message: “’m toxic!”. Spice plots poisonfrogs give dataviz toxic twist! wait, also included color palettes inspired pretty frog species, … ?

title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs

title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs
text: call names xyz colour palettes poisonfrogs: Plot poison frog palettes print hex codes colours every palette:
code: poison_palettes_names() #>  [1] "Afemoralis"      "Afulguritus"     "Amacero"         "Aminutus"        #>  [5] "Ashihuemoy"      "Atrivittata"     "Bpicturata"      "Dauratus"        #>  [9] "Dsarayacuensis"  "Dtalanis"        "Dtazureus"       "Eanthonyi"       #> [13] "Edarwinwallacei" "Etricolor"       "Hcinerascens"    "Hfleischmanni"   #> [17] "Hhobbsi"         "Llineatus"       "Mlaevigata"      "Oanchicayensis"  #> [21] "Ohistrionica"    "Olehmanni"       "Opbluejeans"     "Opcolon"         #> [25] "Opescudo"        "Oploma"          "Opsancristobal"  "Opuyama"         #> [29] "Oscolon"         "Oskoi"           "Oslita"          "Osotokiki"       #> [33] "Ossanantonio"    "Ossp1"           "Pterribilis"     "Ptomopterna"     #> [37] "Pvaillantii"     "Ramazonica"      "Ribanded"        "Ristriped"       #> [41] "Rmarina"         "Rvariabilis" # plot palette with hex codes poison_palette("Hfleischmanni") # get hex codes for a vector cols <- poison_palette("Dtalanis", return = "vector")  cols #> [1] "#090B0A" "#263F48" "#499AC1" "#EEA715" "#FED126"

title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs
code: require(tidyverse) require(gapminder) require(gridExtra) require(ggridges)  #continuous scale  df_nottem <- tibble(   year  = floor(time(nottem)),   month = factor(month.abb[cycle(nottem)], levels = month.abb),   temp  = as.numeric(nottem) )  p1 <- ggplot(df_nottem, aes(x = temp, y = month, fill = after_stat(x))) +   geom_density_ridges_gradient(scale = 2, rel_min_height = 0.01) +   scale_fill_poison(     name = "Oskoi",     type = "continuous",     alpha = 0.95,     direction = -1   ) +   labs(   fill = "ºF",   y = NULL,   x = NULL) +   theme_classic(base_size = 20, base_line_size = 0.5) +   theme(legend.position = "right", legend.justification = "left",   legend.margin = margin(0,0,0,0),   legend.box.margin = margin(-5,-5,-5,-5)) +   coord_cartesian(clip = "off")  p1

title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs
code: #discrete scale 1 p2 <- ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = continent, y = lifeExp, fill = continent)) +   geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.95, outliers = F) +   geom_jitter(     shape = 21,     position = position_jitter(0.1),     alpha = 0.2,     size = 0.8,     bg = "grey"   ) +   stat_summary(     fun = mean,     geom = "point",     size = 1.5,     color = "black",     alpha = 0.6   ) +   theme_classic(base_size = 20, base_line_size = 0.5) +   scale_fill_poison(     name = "Opcolon",     type = "discrete",     alpha = 0.95,     direction = -1   ) +   theme(legend.position = "none") +   xlab(NULL) +   ylab("Life Expentancy")  p2

title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs
code: #discrete scale 2 p3 <- ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = lifeExp, y = log(gdpPercap), colour = continent)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.2) +   scale_colour_poison(name = "Ashihuemoy", type = "discrete") +   stat_smooth() +   facet_wrap(.~continent, scales = "free") +   theme_minimal(20, base_line_size = 0.2) +   theme(legend.position = "none",   strip.background = element_blank(), strip.placement = "outside")   p3

what: Poison-frog palettes: plot or hex codes — poison_palette
title: Poison-frog palettes: plot or hex codes — poison_palette
text: Generate colours poison-frog palette , default, show labelled tiles. Set return = "vector" get hex codes instead (useful programmatic use ggplot2 scale factories).

title: Poison-frog palettes: plot or hex codes — poison_palette
code: poison_palette(   name,   n = NULL,   type = c("discrete", "continuous"),   direction = 1,   alpha = NULL,   return = c("plot", "vector") )

title: Poison-frog palettes: plot or hex codes — poison_palette
text: name Character. Palette name (see poison_palettes_names()). n Integer (optional). Number colours use. Defaults palette length type = "discrete" 256 type = "continuous". type Either "discrete" "continuous". direction Integer. 1 forward, -1 reversed order. alpha Optional numeric [0, 1]. Uniform transparency applied colours. return Either "plot" (default) show tile plot hex labels, "vector" return character vector hex colours.

title: Poison-frog palettes: plot or hex codes — poison_palette
text: return = "plot", ggplot2 object. return = "vector", character vector hex colours.

title: Poison-frog palettes: plot or hex codes — poison_palette
code: # Show a palette as tiles (default) poison_palette("Ramazonica")   # Reverse order and show only 4 colours poison_palette("Ramazonica", n = 4, direction = -1)   # Get a vector with the palette hex codes cols <- poison_palette("Ramazonica", return = "vector")  # Continuous gradient preview (16 swatches) poison_palette("Osotokiki", type = "continuous", n = 16)

title: Poison frog palettes — poison_palettes
text: Poison frog palettes

what: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs — poisonfrogs
title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs — poisonfrogs
text: Provides colour palettes inspired enormous diversity skin colours Neotropical poison frog species. Suitable use ggplot2 base R graphics.

title: Colour Palettes of Neotropical Poison Frogs — poisonfrogs
text: Maintainer: Camilo Rodríguez camilorl@stanford.edu Authors: Lauren O'Connell loconnel@stanford.edu

what: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
title: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
text: colour scale works either discrete continuous data, controlled type. discrete data uses ggplot2::discrete_scale(), continuous data builds smooth gradient ggplot2::scale_colour_gradientn().

title: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
code: scale_colour_poison(   name,   type = c("discrete", "continuous"),   direction = 1,   alpha = NULL,   ... )  scale_color_poison(   name,   type = c("discrete", "continuous"),   direction = 1,   alpha = NULL,   ... )

title: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
text: name Character. Name poison-frog palette use (see poison_palette_names). type Either "discrete" "continuous". Selects kind ggplot2 scale constructed. direction Integer. 1 palette stored order, -1 reverse . alpha Optional numeric [0, 1]. supplied, applies uniform transparency colours (discrete continuous modes). ... Additional arguments passed underlying ggplot2 scale (e.g. limits, breaks, labels, guide, oob, etc.).

title: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
text: ggplot2 scale object.

title: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
text: Discrete: relies internal function factory poison_pal() returns n colours demand ggplot2::discrete_scale(). Continuous: generates 256-colour gradient via poison_palette() (type "continuous") passes ggplot2::scale_colour_gradientn().

title: Poison frog colour scale for ggplot2 — scale_colour_poison
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(ggplot2) library(gapminder)  # Discrete example ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = lifeExp, y = log(gdpPercap), colour = continent)) +  geom_point(alpha = 0.2) +  scale_colour_poison(name = "Ramazonica", type = "discrete") +  stat_smooth() +  facet_wrap(. ~ continent, scales = "free") +  theme_minimal(21, base_line_size = 0.2) +  theme(    legend.position = "none",    strip.background = element_blank(),    strip.placement = "outside"    )  # Continuous example ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, colour = disp)) +  geom_point(size = 3) +  scale_colour_poison("Dtalanis", type = "continuous", direction = -1) +  stat_smooth(col = "black") +  theme_classic(base_size = 32, base_line_size = 0.5) } # }

what: Poison frog fill scale for ggplot2 — scale_fill_poison
title: Poison frog fill scale for ggplot2 — scale_fill_poison
text: unified fill scale works either discrete continuous data, controlled type. discrete data uses ggplot2::discrete_scale(), continuous data builds smooth gradient ggplot2::scale_fill_gradientn().

title: Poison frog fill scale for ggplot2 — scale_fill_poison
code: scale_fill_poison(   name,   type = c("discrete", "continuous"),   direction = 1,   alpha = NULL,   ... )

title: Poison frog fill scale for ggplot2 — scale_fill_poison
text: name Character. Name poison-frog palette use (see poison_palette_names). type Either "discrete" "continuous". Selects kind ggplot2 scale constructed. direction Integer. 1 palette stored order, -1 reverse . alpha Optional numeric [0, 1]. supplied, applies uniform transparency colours (discrete continuous modes). ... Additional arguments passed underlying ggplot2 scale (e.g. limits, breaks, labels, guide, oob, etc.).

title: Poison frog fill scale for ggplot2 — scale_fill_poison
text: ggplot2 scale object.

title: Poison frog fill scale for ggplot2 — scale_fill_poison
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(ggplot2) library(gapminder)  # Discrete example ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = continent, y = lifeExp, fill = continent)) + geom_violin(trim = FALSE, alpha = 0.75) + geom_jitter(  shape = 21,  position = position_jitter(0.1),  alpha = 0.3,  size = 0.8,  bg = "grey"  ) + stat_summary(  fun = mean,  geom = "point",  size = 1.5,  color = "black",  alpha = 0.6  ) + theme_classic(base_size = 32, base_line_size = 0.5) + scale_fill_poison(  name = "Ramazonica",  type = "discrete",  alpha = 0.95,  direction = -1  ) + theme(legend.position = "none") + xlab(NULL)  # Continuous example ggplot(df_nottem, aes(x = temp, y = month, fill = stat(x))) + geom_density_ridges_gradient(scale = 2, rel_min_height = 0.01) + scale_fill_poison(  name = "Ramazonica",  type = "continuous",  alpha = 0.95,  direction = 1  ) + labs( fill = "ºF") + theme_light(base_size = 26, base_line_size = 0.5) + theme(  legend.position = "right",  legend.justification = "left",  legend.margin = margin(0,0,0,0),  legend.box.margin = margin(-20,-20,-20,-20)  ) } # }
